title: 109_hr1598
content: The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" improves veterans' benefits for former prisoners of war. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" repeals the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases under title 38, United States Code. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" repeals the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases under title 38, United States Code. Following this, additional diseases such as heart disease, stroke, diabetes (type 2), and osteoporosis are now presumed to be service-connected. The Secretary has the authority for administrative determination of presumption of service connection for these additional diseases. The Secretary can establish a presumption of service connection for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war based on medical evidence. Recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War are considered in making these determinations. The Secretary evaluates medical and scientific information to establish a presumption of service connection for diseases related to being a prisoner of war. If credible evidence supports the association, it will be considered positive. Recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War must be acted upon within 60 days. The Secretary evaluates medical and scientific information to establish a presumption of service connection for diseases. If warranted, proposed regulations are issued within 60 days. If not warranted, a notice is published with an explanation. The Secretary evaluates medical and scientific information to establish a presumption of service connection for diseases. Proposed regulations are issued within 60 days if warranted, or a notice is published if the presumption is not warranted. Regulations removing the presumption for a disease must be issued within 90 days, with compensation entitlements maintained for affected veterans and survivors. The Secretary will consult with the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War when implementing regulations for entitlement to compensation for specified diseases. Amendments to section 1112(b) include provisions for prescribed diseases under subsection (d).
